newsitem.title: SPAIN: BoS inflation forecast supports goal - Spain's Rato.
newsitem.headline: BoS inflation forecast supports goal - Spain's Rato.

text.p: Spanish Economy Minister Rodrigo Rato said on Wednesday the Bank of Spain's inflation forecast shows the new government target is not too optimistic.

"(Bank of Spain's forecast) should send a message of calmness that our target is not ambitious..although it is the most ambitious in Spanish history," Rato told reporters before giving a speech in Madrid.
Earlier on Wednesday, the Bank of Spain's governor said Spanish inflation could end the year below two percent.
Recently the Spanish government reduced its inflation goal to 2.2 percent for the year from a previous 2.6 percent.
Rato added that recent data showed that Spain was now in a more stable economic trend.

"It's not only that the economy is growing at three percent in a sustained way, but also that price tensions are fading away...at the same time we are improving our export situation," Rato said referring to the latest trade balance figure.
Spain's trade deficit fell in the first quarter by 22 percent to 471.3 billion pesetas ($3.3 billion) from 604.4 billion pesetas in the first three monthS of 1996.
